author: palladia
body: Can't seem to change the policy.  Zack believes that Andy has hard-coded the value.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: ExecutionPolicy is not a thing on Linux.

comments.author: palladia
comments.body: Execution-Policy isn't a thing on WIndows either, until PowerShell came along.  The question is, does it make sense to implement ExecutionPolicy on Linux, or just let all scripts run unrestricted?

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
In my opinion, if a user installed PowerShell the interpreter on Linux, they would expect to be able to use it to run scripts, so an ExecutionPolicy preventing it would not make a lot of sense.

@FawcettJohnW do you think we should implement a "system policy" of some sort to disable PowerShell script execution?

comments.author: palladia
comments.body:
If you believe in the concept of signing files (scripts, dll’s, etc.), then it seems to make sense to implement some sort of restrictions.
